{{Year nav topic5|1649|music}}
The year '''1649 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
==Popular music== *[[Gerrard Winstanley]] – "[[Diggers' Song]]"<ref>[[s:Diggers' Song|wikisource]]</ref>
==Classical music== *[[Johann Jakob Froberger]] – ''Libro secondo di toccate, fantasie, canzone, allemande, courante, sarabande, gigue et altre partite'' (presentation manuscript, September) *[[Alberich Mazak]] – ''Cultus harmonicus'', volume one, a collection of his complete works, published in [[Vienna]]
==[[Opera]]== *Pietro Cavalli – ''Jason'' *[[Antonio Cesti]] – ''Orontea'', premiéred at the Teatro Santissimi Apostoli, in [[Venice]], during [[Carnival]]e.
==Births== *[[February 23]] – [[John Blow]], organist and composer *[[May 3]] (bapt.) – [[Johann Valentin Meder]], organist and composer (d. [[1719 in music|1719]]) *''date unknown'' – [[Johann Krieger]], composer **[[John Blow]], organist and composer *''probable'' – [[Jacques Boyvin]], French organist and composer (died 1706)
==Deaths== *[[April 29]]/[[April 30|30]] – [[Giovanni Valentini]], keyboard virtuoso and composer.
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: A Time for Tea: Women, Labor and Post-colonial Politics on an India Plantation

revision.comment: Edit for links only for the following: "plantation", Edward Said, Lewis Carroll, The Australian Journal of Anthropology, The American Historical Review, "anthropology"
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=September 2015}} {{Orphan|date=April 2015}} }}
'''''Time for Tea: Women, Labor and Post-colonial Politics on an Indian Plantation''''' (2011) is a [[Postcolonial feminism|post-colonial feminist]] ethnographic critique of labour practices in [[India]]n [[tea]] [[plantation]]<nowiki/>s. Through personal interviews, anecdotes and a play, Piya Chatterjee examines the role gender, class, and race play in the production, consumption and circulation of tea. Transcending the realm of local politics and culture, the ethnography reveals the multilayered, multispatial, colonial dimension of gendered labour. She begins by deconstructing the image of the tea box itself to showcase how the image of the exotic tea-plucking women distracts the consumer from the harsh working conditions of plantations. By providing a historical account of the tea industry in India, Chatterjee reveals the intricate link between colonialism and the gendered division of labour in North Bengalese plantations. While gender is her main unit of analysis, Chatterjee explores the way in which colonialism has shaped and continues to shape, the patriarchal and class-based nature of plantations. Coming from a [[Global South]] perspective, she demonstrates the intersectionality of gender, class and race, as mutually constitutive mechanisms of oppression. Throughout the novel, she acknowledges her own privilege as a Global South academic and highlights the difficulties of speaking for the [[Subaltern (postcolonialism)|subaltern]].
== Awards == * Recipient of the John Franklin Hope Book Award from [[Duke University]] press.<ref>[http://www.dukeupress.edu. Duke University Press. 2001."A Time for Tea."]</ref>
==Review == * “A kaleiodoscopic account of the phenomenon of tea, incorporating dramatic interludes via [[Antonin Artaud]]’s theatre of the absurd, the poetics of [[Edward Said]] and the opiatic imagination of [[Lewis Carroll]], depicting the role tea plays in the high and low drama of empire building as it was and remain in transformation.”<ref>Courtney, Sheleyah A. 2004. A time for tea: Women, labor, and Post/Colonial politics on an indian plantation. ''The Australian Journal of Anthropology'' 15, (1): 111.</ref>–''[[The Australian Journal of Anthropology]]'' * “Those searching for an argument about the postcolonial tea economy, or to learn the history of trade unionism on the North Bengal Tea plantation, or even to gain a better understanding of the complexity of gender, caste, and ethnic relations in the region will be disappointed. […] Her book is more properly read as a meditative and reflective work and deserves to be judged on these terms.”<ref>Visweswaran, Kamala. 2003. "Piya Chatterjee. A Time for Tea: Women, Labor, and Post/Colonial Politics On an Indian Plantation." ''The American Historical Review'' 108, (2): 499-500.</ref>-''[[The American Historical Review]]''
== About the author== Piya Chatterjee is a [[Historical anthropology|historical anthropologist]] with a current position at the [[University of California]] as a [[Women’s Studies]] Assistant professor.<ref>[https://www.amazon.ca/Time-Tea-Colonial-Politics-Plantation/dp/0822326744 Amazon. 2008. "A Time for Tea."]</ref> She self identifies as a post/colonial immigrant women.<ref>Chatterjee, Piya. 2002. "Encountering "Third World Women": Rac(e)ing the Global in a U.S. Classroom." ''Pedagogy 2.1'': 79-108. Project MUSE. Web. 8 Apr. 2015. [https://muse.jhu.edu/]</ref> Born from Indian parents in Nigeria, her family moved to Northern [[India]] become immigrating to the [[United States]].<ref>Chatterjee 2002, 80.</ref> She received her PhD. in [[Anthropology]], with a focus on Western Asia, from the University of Chicago in 1994.<ref>University of [[California]] Riverside. 2013."Women and Tea Plantations Topics of Library’s Meet-The-Author Event at UC Riverside." [http://newsroom.ucr.edu/521]</ref> Academically she describes herself as a “a disciple of Paulo Freire, with a strong postcolonial and antiracist feminist twist."<ref>Jadaliyya. 2014. "New Texts Out Now: Sunaina Maira and Piya Chatterjee, The Imperial University: Academic Repression and Scholarly Dissent."Interview by Jadaliyya. [http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/17695/new-texts-out-now_sunaina-maira-and-piya-chatterje]</ref> She is currently working on a book titled Decolonizing Pedagogies.<ref>Chatterjee interview by Jadaliyya, 2014.</ref> Her research is focused on the theories of pedagogy and what education means across borders, from her University classroom to villages in post-colonial India.<ref>Chatterjee interview by Jadaliyya, 2014.</ref> Her future projects include a decolonizing memoir, which she plans to title ''“Going Ape”: Racisms, Violence and Resistance in the US Academy''. Her objective is to develop an ethnographic critique about the cultural and political practices of academia from a postcolonial perspective.<ref>Chatterjee interview by Jadaliyya, 2014.</ref>
== Other publications == *Chatterjee, Piya, and Manalia Desai. 2009. ''States of Trauma: Gender and Violence in South Asia''. Zubaan Press. * Chatterjee, Piya, and Sunaina Maira. 2014. ''The Imperial University: Academic Repression and Scholarly Dissent''. University of Minnesota Press. * Chatterjee, Piya. 2008. ''Comparative Perspectives Symposium: Women’s Labour Activism''. University of Chicago Press.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Time for Tea, A}} [[Category:Feminist literature]] [[Category:Feminism and society]] [[Category:Tea industry in India]] [[Category:Women in India]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Anne Henslow Barnard | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Anne Henslow | birth_date = {{Birth year|1833}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1899|1|19|1833|mf=y}} | death_place = | nationality = British | education = | field = [[Botanical Illustration]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | awards = | spouse = {{marriage|Robert Cary Barnard|1859|}} | partner = }}
'''Anne Henslow Barnard''' (1833–1899) was a 19th-century botanical artist.
[[File:Lacaena spectabilis - Curtis' 106 (Ser. 3 no. 36) pl 6516 (1880).jpg|thumb|''Lacaena spectabilis'' illustrated by Anne Henslow Barnard in Curtis's Botanical Magazine]] ==Biography== Anne Henslow was born in 1833.<ref name=natstand/><ref name=birth/> She was the youngest daughter<ref name=walters/> of botanist and Cambridge University professor [[John Stevens Henslow]] and Harriet Jenyns, who was the daughter of clergyman [[George Leonard Jenyns]] and the sister of naturalist [[Leonard Jenyns]].<ref name=jenyns/>{{rp|46}} Her older sister [[Frances Harriet Hooker|Frances Harriet]] married botanist [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]],<ref name=jenyns/>{{rp|264}} and one of her brothers, George, became a professor of botany.<ref name=maries/>
In 1859 she married army officer Robert Cary Barnard, who was the son of an old friend of her father's.<ref name=walters/><ref name=darwin/> They had eight children.<ref name=natstand/><ref name=darwin2/>
Barnard's father was one of the first Cambridge University professors to give illustrated lectures, for which he used poster-size illustrations. Some of these were based on rough sketches by Barnard that were then finished by the botanical artist [[Walter Hood Fitch]].<ref name=porter/>
She contributed plates to ''[[Curtis's Botanical Magazine]]'' in the years 1879–94.<ref name=desmond/> She also illustrated [[Daniel Oliver]]'s 1864 ''Lessons in Elementary Biology'', which was built on a manuscript left by her father. It stayed in print for several decades.<ref name=desmond/> Although her output was not large, she was considered a very fine botanical artist.<ref name=harris/>
She died on 19 January 1899.<ref name=desmond/>
==Notes and references== {{Wikicommons}} {{reflist | refs =
<ref name=natstand>[http://www.natstand.org.uk/pdf/HenslowJS000.pdf "The Henslow family – Relationships Relative to John Stevens Henslow. "]. Natstand, March 6, 2015, updated Dec. 4, 2015. Accessed Dec. 23, 2015.</ref>
<ref name=walters>Walters, Stuart Max, and Elizabeth Anne Stow. ''Darwin's Mentor: John Stevens Henslow, 1796-1861''. Cambridge University Press, 2001, pp. 19–20; 271.</ref>
<ref name=birth>Dates given for Barnard's birth year vary considerably in different sources. The Darwin Correspondence Project gives 1833 or 1834, while Darwin, Burkhardt, and Porter gives 1825, probably a mistake for her sister Frances Harriet. The preponderance of evidence appears to support 1833.</ref>
<ref name=darwin2>Darwin, Charles, Frederick Burkhardt, and Duncan M. Porter. ''The Correspondence of Charles Darwin''. Vol. 8. Vol. 1860. Cambridge University Press, 2002, p. 290.</ref>
<ref name=harris>Harris, Barbara Jean, and Jo Ann McNamara. ''Women and the Structure of Society: Selected research from the Fifth Berkshire Conference on the History of Women''. Duke University Press, 1984, p.70.</ref>
<ref name=darwin>[https://www.darwinproject.ac.uk/person/namedef-285 "Anne Barnard"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226065619/https://www.darwinproject.ac.uk/person/namedef-285 |date=December 26, 2015 }}. Darwin Correspondence Project, University of Cambridge, 2015. Accessed Dec. 23, 2015.</ref>
<ref name=porter>Porter, Duncan, and Peter Graham. ''Darwin's Sciences''. John Wiley & Sons, 2015.</ref>
<ref name=desmond>Desmond, Ray, ed. ''Dictionary of British and Irish Botantists and Horticulturalists''. CRC Press, 1994.</ref>
<ref name=jenyns>Jenyns, Leonard. ''Memoir of the Rev. John Stevens Henslow''. John Van Voorst, London, 1862.</ref>
<ref name=maries>[http://www.hamptonlucy.net/About/VEG/charlesmaries.html "The Life and Times of Charles Maries"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723142431/http://www.hamptonlucy.net/About/VEG/charlesmaries.html |date=2011-07-23 }}</ref>
}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barnard, Anne Henslow}} [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:Botanical illustrators]] [[Category:British illustrators]] [[Category:British women artists]] [[Category:19th-century women artists]]

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{primary sources|date=April 2013}}
The '''Australian International Design Awards''' is an industry body established by the [[Industrial Design Council of Australia]] (IDCA), founded in 1958. The awards are [[Australia|Australia's]] only national design awards for [[industrial design]]. Since 1991, the Australian International Design Awards has been a division of [[Standards Australia]].
In 2007 the Australian Design Awards expanded its entry criteria to include all professionally designed products on the Australian market, including products designed in Australia. From 2007, the Australian Design Awards became known as the Australian International Design Awards to reflect the global nature of the awards.
The Australian International Design Awards has been recognised by the [[Government of Australia|Commonwealth Government]] and the International Council of Societies of Industrial Design<ref>[http://www.icsid.org ICSID] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906041307/http://www.icsid.org/ |date=6 September 2009 }}.org</ref> as a promotional body for the Australian design industry.
== Awards == There are three types of accolades issued by the Australian International Design Awards,<ref>[http://designawards.com.au/accolades.jsp Designawards.com.au] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912113443/http://designawards.com.au/accolades.jsp |date=12 September 2009 }}</ref> they are: * Australian International Design Mark (recognising Good Design) * Australian International Design Award (recognising Design Excellence) * Australian International Design Award of the Year (recognising the best product of the year)
Special Awards include: * Award for Excellence in Sustainable Design<ref>[http://designawards.com.au/sustainable_design.jsp Sustainable design] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912140502/http://designawards.com.au/sustainable_design.jsp |date=12 September 2009 }}</ref> * Powerhouse Museum Design Award and Selection<ref>[http://designawards.com.au/powerhouse_museum_selection.jsp Powerhouse museum selection] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912124235/http://designawards.com.au/powerhouse_museum_selection.jsp |date=12 September 2009 }}</ref> * Wheels Automotive Design Award<ref>[http://designawards.com.au/wheels.jsp Wheels] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912140422/http://designawards.com.au/wheels.jsp |date=12 September 2009 }}</ref>
== History == {{refimprove section|date=April 2013}} In 1958 the Industrial Design Council of Australia (IDCA) was established<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=362218|title=Industrial Design Council of Australia Archive|website=www.powerhousemuseum.com}}</ref> funded by the Commonwealth Government. The goal was to educate [[Manufacturer|manufacturers]] and consumers on the value of design, encourage and promote high standards of design in [[Manufacturing|manufactured]] goods.
From 1964 Good Design Labels began to appear on products and the Australian Design Index became a register of the best designed products in Australia. A panel of experts reviewed items for inclusion in the Index. Products meeting the criteria received the Good Design Label and other manufacturers were given constructive criticism on how to improve their products.
In 1964, the IDCA opened the first Australian Design Centre in [[Melbourne]] with a special exhibition of selected products from the Australian Design Index. Federal and state government funding helped establish a new Design Centre in [[Sydney]], with more centres to follow in other cities.
In 1967 the Prince Philip Prize for Australian Design was set up, supported by [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]], with the aim of promoting greater awareness of good design in Australian [[engineering]]. The inaugural Prince Philip Prize was awarded in 1968.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wong|first1=Ian|title=Prince Philip Prize - STILL Winners|url=http://ianwongresearch.blogspot.com.au/2011/10/prince-phillip-design-prize-still.html|website=Industrial Design in Victoria|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref> Over 90 entries were received and the winning entry was a self-propelled grain header, designed by Kenneth Gibson. The Prince Philip Prize continued for twenty years.
The IDCA faced funding difficulties in the mid-1970s and was forced to close temporarily in 1976. A new funding injection from the Commonwealth Government helped the Council reopen and a new 'innovation' recognition program was introduced.
Recognising not only high quality but innovative Australian designed products, the Australian Design Award (ADA) program became a valuable promotional tool for manufacturers and designers and provided a source of revenue for the IDCA to continue its operations. The Prince Philip Prize continued to be awarded, but only to products which had received the ADA.
During this time, publicity was at an all-time high. Televised coverage of the Awards presentation on [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC TV]] reached audiences of over four million and in 1979, the first annual yearbook of ADA winners was published.
For the next two decades, however, continuing funding issues, dwindling industry support and a lack of clear direction plagued the IDCA. In 1987 in an effort to reinvigorate the movement, the government re-launched the IDCA as the Australian Design Council and the Prince Philip Prize was folded, leaving the ADA as Australia's top design accolade.
In 1991, control of the Australian Design Council and the ADA program moved to [[Standards Australia]]. Under Standards Australia, the ADA program continued to run, but the Australian Design Council was disbanded in 1993. New formats and incentives for the ADA program such as the Australian Design Mark certification scheme were trialled during the second half of the '90s without success. In 1997 a revamped format was introduced to the Awards, using an online application form and first round internet shortlisting. It attracted more than one hundred applications. The first Presentation Night was held at the [[The Metro Theatre|Metro Theatre]] in Sydney. In 1998, profession-based categories were introduced.
However, the program was threatened by significant [[operating costs]]. The 1999 program was put on hold while Standards Australia explored other options to secure the future of the awards. The majority of staff was made redundant and for the first time in many years, no Design Awards were presented in Australia. The Design Institute of Australia was approached to take over the program but the financial commitment to posed too great a risk.
Armed with a new business plan and financial model, the Board of Standards Australia approved another year for the awards. For the next few years, the ADA continued to grow in standing and support, buoyed by financial stability. A student design category was launched in 2002 supported by [[Dyson (company)|Dyson Appliances]] Australia and in 2004, product-focused categories were introduced.
In 2008, on the 50th anniversary of rewarding design and innovation excellence in Australia, internationally designed products available for sale in Australia were allowed to enter the awards for the first time. This bold move was aimed at raising the stakes for good design once again, allowing Australian design to be benchmarked against the best in the world. With the ongoing support of the design industry and Standards Australia, this opens the door to the next chapter in the history of the Design Awards.<ref>[http://designawards.com.au/retrospective.jsp 50 Year Retrospective of the Australian International Design Awards 1958–2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003130032/http://designawards.com.au/retrospective.jsp |date=3 October 2009 }}</ref>
== Previous winners == Previous winners include:
* [[Caroma]]'s Invisi Series II Toilet Suite<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?applicationID=4421|title=Caroma Invisi Series II Toilet Suite|website=designawards.com.au}}</ref> and H2Zero Cube Urinal<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?applicationID=581&status=8|title=Caroma H2Zero Cube Urinal|website=designawards.com.au}}</ref> * Qantas A380 Economy Class Seat<ref>[http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?status=10&applicationID=4871&year=2009m 2009 Australian International Design Award of the Year] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706103541/http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?status=10&applicationID=4871&year=2009m |date=6 July 2011 }}</ref> designed by [[Marc Newson]], * [[Ford XE Falcon]] * 1987 [[Mitsubishi Magna]] wagon<ref>{{cite journal|title=Driving your World|date=2001|issue=Sydney Motor Show|publisher=[[Mitsubishi Motors Australia Limited]]}}</ref> * [[Holden VT Commodore]] * [[Ford AU Falcon]] * [[Ford Territory (Australia)|Ford Territory]] * [[Holden Commodore]] VE Sportswagon and Ute * Blueye Sport Goggle designed by [[Paul Cohen (designer)|Paul Cohen]] * Victa [[Lawn Mower]] * [[Bionic Ear]] * [[winged keel]] * VentrAssist [[Artificial Heart]] * [[Sunbeam Products|Sunbeam]] Mixmaster * Test Series Cricket Helmet * [[Røde Microphones|RØDE]] Podcaster microphone<ref>[http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?status=8&applicationID=595 The Rode Podcaster – Australian International Design Awards<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927180358/http://www.designawards.com.au/application_detail.jsp?status=8&applicationID=595 |date=27 September 2007 }}</ref> * Dolphin Torch * Enzie Spiral Stair
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [https://www.good-design.com/ Australian Good Design Awards] * [http://www.standards.org.au/ Standards Australia] * [http://www.facebook.com/pages/Australian-International-Design-Awards/128520735904 AIDA Facebook Page]
[[Category:Awards established in 1958]] [[Category:Design awards]] [[Category:Industrial design]] [[Category:Australian awards|Design Award]] [[Category:1958 establishments in Australia]]

{{refstyle|date=February 2013}} [[File:Hay-On-Wye Booksellers - geograph.org.uk - 235428.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Bookshop in Hay-on-Wye]] [[Image:Wigtown book shop.JPG|frame|right|Scotland's largest second-hand bookshop]]
A '''book town''' is a town or village with a large number of [[used book]] or antiquarian [[Used bookstore|book stores]]. These [[Bookselling|stores]], as well as [[literary festival]]s, attract [[Bibliophilia|bibliophile]] tourists. A number of the book towns are members of the International Organisation of Book Towns.
== List of book towns == ===Book towns with known dates of operation=== *[[Jinbōchō, Tokyo|Jinbōchō]], Tokyo, Japan (early 1880s) *[[Hay-on-Wye]], Wales (1961) *[[Redu]], Belgium (1984) *[[Bécherel]], France (1988) *[[Montolieu]], France (1989) *[[Bredevoort]], Netherlands (1993) *[[Stillwater, Minnesota]], U.S. (1993)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.booktown.com |title=Booktown.com |publisher=Booktown.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-02}}</ref> *[[Saint-Pierre-de-Clages]], Switzerland (1993) *[[Fontenoy-la-Joûte]], France (1993) *[[Mundal]], [[Fjærland]], Norway (1995) *[[Wigtown]], Scotland (1997) *[[Zossen|Zossen-Wünsdorf]], Germany (1997) *[[Damme]], Belgium (1997) *[[Dalmellington]], Scotland (1997, though the last bookseller closed in 2005 and the project has folded)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inprint.co.uk/thebookguide/shops/dalmellington_book_town.php |title=Dalmellington Book Town - on the road to nowhere |work=TheBookGuide |author=Goodenough, Mike |date=11 April 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720064018/http://www.inprint.co.uk/thebookguide/shops/dalmellington_book_town.php |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> *[[Sysmä]], Finland (4 July 1997) *[[Mühlbeck]]-[[Friedersdorf, Saxony-Anhalt|Friedersdorf]], Germany (1997) *[[Kampung Buku Langkawi]], Malaysia (3 December 1997) *[[Archer City, Texas]], U.S. (1999) *Booktown Richmond, Great Karoo South Africa (2006) *[[Southern Highlands, New South Wales|Southern Highlands]], Australia (2000) *[[Mellösa]], Sweden (17 February 2001)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idehjulet.se/bokstaden/english.htm |title=The Book Town in Mellösa |date=9 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308103539/http://www.idehjulet.se/bokstaden/english.htm |archivedate=8 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> *[[Tvedestrand]], Norway (2003) *[[Sedbergh]], England (2003) *[[Blaenavon]], Wales (28 June 2003,<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/jun/28/arts.achapterfrombooktown |title=Books open new chapter for Plywood City |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=28 June 2003|last1=Kennedy |first1=Maev |last2=Correspondent |first2=Heritage }}</ref> though the project had folded by March 2006)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inprint.co.uk/thebookguide/shops/wales/blaenafon_booktown_fails.shtml |title=Blaenafon - The Booktown Experiment Fails |work=TheBookGuide |author=Goodenough, Mike |date=17 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703153930/http://www.inprint.co.uk/thebookguide/shops/wales/blaenafon_booktown_fails.shtml |archivedate=3 July 2010 |df= }}</ref> *[[Brownville, Nebraska]], U.S., (2004)<ref>[http://www.brownville-ne.com](www.brownville-ne.com)</ref> *[[Hobart, NY]] - Book Village of the Catskills<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hobartbookvillage.com |title=For Those Who Love Books - Home |publisher=Hobartbookvillage.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-02}}</ref> (2005) *[[Atherstone]], [[Warwickshire]] (2005) *Torup, [[Denmark]] (2006) <ref>[http://www.torupbogby.dk torupbogby.dk]. Torup Bogby home page.</ref> *[[Kampung Buku Melaka]], Malaysia <ref>[http://www.bookvillage.com.my Book Village Malaysia]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> (17 April 2007) *[[St. Martins, New Brunswick]], Canada (2007){{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *[[Urueña]], Spain (2007) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diputaciondevalladolid.es/villadellibro/presentacion.shtml |title=Turismo Provincia de Valladolid |publisher=Diputaciondevalladolid.es |date= |accessdate=2013-05-02}}</ref> *[[Bellprat]], [[Catalonia]] (2008) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.viladelllibre.cat/bellprat |title=Bellprat Vila del Llibre |publisher=www.viladelllibre.cat |date= |accessdate=2013-05-02}}</ref> * [[Esquelbecq]], France (2010) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esquelbook.com|website=esquelbook.com|title=Esquelbook le site d'Esquelbecq, Village du Livre|language=French|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> *[[Clunes, Victoria]], Australia (2012) * Montereggio [[Mulazzo]], Italy * [[Borrby]], Sweden (2011) * [[Óbidos, Portugal|Óbidos]], Portugal (2015) * [[Featherston, New Zealand]] (2015) * [[Cervera]], Catalonia (2016) * [[Montblanc, Tarragona|Montblanc]], Catalonia (2017) *[[Bhilar, Maharashtra]], India (2017)
===Book Towns with unknown dates of operation=== *[[Sidney, British Columbia]] *[booktown-yean], South Korea (2017) *Gold Cities BookTown, [[Grass Valley, California]]
